{{coord|40.7032|-74.0091|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=title}} {{Infobox building |name = 55 Water Street |status = Complete |image = 55 Water Street and north wing.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = |location = |coordinates = |start_date = 1969 |completion_date = 1972 |architect = [[Emery Roth & Sons]]
[[Lee Jablin|Lee S. Jablin]] |owner = [[Retirement Systems of Alabama]] |cost = |floor_area = {{convert|3.5|e6sqft|m2|sigfig=3}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 53 |references = |building_type = Office | architectural_style = [[International Style (architecture)|international style]] |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|687|ft|m|abbr=on}} |elevator_count = |structural_engineer= The Office of James Ruderman |main_contractor = |opening = |developer = [[Uris Buildings Corporation]] |management = }} '''55 Water Street''' is a {{convert|687|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} [[skyscraper]] in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]], on the [[East River]]. The 53-story, {{convert|3.5|e6sqft|m2|sigfig=3|adj=on}} structure was completed in 1972. [[Emery Roth & Sons]] designed the building, which is tied with [[277 Park Avenue]] as the 40th-tallest building in New York City. When it was completed it was the largest office building in the world, and is still the largest in New York by floor area. In an arrangement with the Office of Lower Manhattan Development, it was built on a [[city block#Superblock|superblock]] created from four adjoining city blocks, suppressing the western part of Front Street. Its closest competitors in square footage are the [[Met Life Building]] at {{convert|3140000|sqft}} and [[111 Eighth Avenue]] at {{convert|2900000|sqft}}. [[One World Trade Center]] has roughly the same square footage (3.5 million square feet). The now-destroyed [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] was bigger when it opened in 1973. ==Description== On the north side of the tower is a 15-story wing with a sloping facade and terraces facing the river. The largest terrace forms a [[privately owned public space]] known as the "Elevated Acre", about 30 feet above street level and accessible via escalator and stairs from the sidewalk on Water Street. The creation of public space allowed the developers to increase the total square footage of 55 Water Street beyond what zoning regulations would otherwise have allowed on the site. The Elevated Acre was originally planned as part of a series of high-level public spaces along East River, to be connected with walkways running above the street level. The Elevated Acre is available for rental as a venue for special events and weddings and during the summer months occasionally hosts free movie screenings open to the community. The original {{convert|4800|m2|sqft|adj=on}} plaza was designed by [[M. Paul Friedberg]] & Associates, and had the same red brick tiles as his Jeannette Park to the south of the tower. In early 2001, [[Goldman Sachs]] briefly considered leasing space in 55 Water Street and proposed building a 13-story, 240-foot addition on the plaza site which would have included seven large trading floors. The plan also proposed adding 35 feet to the north tower. To compensate for the loss of public space, Goldman Sachs proposed paying for various improvements of public space nearby. The plans were quickly dropped and Goldman Sachs cited economic conditions as the reason although some neighborhood residents had begun to voice opposition.{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} The building, its plazas and Jeannette Park have been renovated and redesigned by [[Lee Jablin|Lee S. Jablin]] of Harman Jablin Architects. The Elevated Acre was renovated in 2005 by Rogers Marvel Architects and Ken Smith Landscape Architects.{{cite news| last=Dunlap | first= David W. | title= Putting a Shine on a Memorial Long Forlorn | publisher= The New York Times| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/24/nyregion/commercial-real-estate-putting-shine-memorial-long-forlorn-project-will-reshape.html?pagewanted=all |date= May 24, 2000 |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}{{cite news| first= David W. |last= Dunlap |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/28/nyregion/commercial-real-estate-a-plaza-few-use-but-everyone-wants.html |title=Commercial Real Estate; A Plaza Few Use But Everyone Wants |publisher=The New York Times |date=February 28, 2001 |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}{{cite news|first=David W.|last= Dunlap |date=March 7, 2001 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/07/nyregion/goldman-sachs-drops-plans-for-new-tower-at-plaza-site.html |title=Goldman Sachs Drops Plans For New Tower at Plaza Site |publisher= The New York Times |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.downtownexpress.com/de_128/7millionplazareachingahigh.html |title=$7 million plaza reaching a higher level reopens |publisher=DowntownExpress.com |accessdate=December 1, 2013}} 55 Water Street was the last major building built by [[Uris Buildings Corporation]].{{cite web |url= http://www.emporis.com/company/uris-brothers-new-york-city-ny-usa |title=Uris Brothers | Companies |publisher=Emporis |date= |accessdate=December 1, 2013}} ==History== From 1973 to 1983, the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] maintained a branch museum in the building; space was rented for a token fee and the operating cost was paid for by several [[Wall Street]] corporations.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} Since 1993, the building has been owned by [[Retirement Systems of Alabama]] who acquired it from [[Olympia & York]].{{cite news|date= October 10, 1993 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/10/realestate/postings-55-water-street-new-start-for-a-troubled-building.html |title=55 Water Street: New Start for a Troubled Building |publisher= The New York Times |accessdate=2013-12-01}} On October 29, 2012, the building was among many along the Lower Manhattan waterfront that sustained [[Effects of Hurricane Sandy in New York|damage related to Hurricane Sandy]] when over {{convert |32|e6USgal|kl}} of water flooded three underground levels and rose to waist-high in the lobby. On November 23, 2012, while repairs were being conducted a fire caused injuries to 27 people—mostly those working on the lower levels.{{cite news|title=NYC high-rise fire leaves 27 with smoke inhalation|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-nyc-high-rise-fire-leaves-27-with-smoke-inhalation-2012nov23-story.html|work=The San-Diego Union Tribune|agency=The Associated Press|date=November 23, 2012}} To prepare for future storms the building's owner plans to relocate electrical equipment from the basement to the third floor starting in late 2013.{{cite web|last=[[Steve Cuozzo|Cuozzo]] |first=Steve |url= https://nypost.com/2012/12/04/waiting-for-water-street/ |title=Waiting for Water Street |publisher=New York Post |date=2012-12-04 |accessdate=2013-12-01}} A flood control infrastructure was also installed around the perimeter of the building to mitigate any flooding should a storm of similar magnitude effect the location in the future. ==Tenants== The building is the headquarters of [[EmblemHealth]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20130512220254/http://www.emblemhealth.com/pdf/eh_lg_app.pdf "Large Employer Group Application"]. EmblemHealth. Retrieved on August 12, 2011. "EmblemHealth, 55 Water Street, New York, New York 10041 HIP Insurance Company of New York, 55 Water Street, New York, NY 10041 Group Health Incorporated, 441 Ninth Avenue, New York, NY 10001" [[EmblemHealth#Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP)|HIP Health Plan of New York]], which became a part of EmblemHealth, moved there with 2,000 employees in October 2004. It was the largest corporate relocation in downtown Manhattan following the [[September 11 attacks]].[http://www.emblemhealth.com/default.aspx?Page=50020 "HIP Celebrates Opening of New Headquarters in Lower Manhattan; Relocation of 2,000 Employees to 55 Water Street Represents Largest Corporate Relocation to Lower Manhattan Since 9/11"] ''HIP Health Plan''. (October 12, 2004). Retrieved on August 12, 2011. [[Standard & Poor's]], a corporate rating agency, [[FXCM]], a [[foreign exchange market|forex]] broker and the [[Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation]] are also headquartered in the building."[http://www.standardandpoors.com/about-sp/office-locations/en/us Office Locations]." Standard & Poor's. Retrieved on August 12, 2011. "Corporate 55 Water Street New York New York ""[http://www.fxcm.com/support/contact-client-support/ FXCM Contact Information]." {{Retrieved|accessdate=2013-11-10}} The [[New York City Department of Transportation]] also has offices in the building.{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/contactdot/assist.shtml |title=NYC Dot |publisher=NYC.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-12-01}} [[McGraw Hill Financial]], parent of Standard & Poor's, moved its headquarters from its [[1221 Avenue of the Americas|namesake building]] to 55 Water Street in June 2015.{{cite web|title=McGraw Hill Moves Downtown, Says Goodbye to Namesake Building|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2015/07/08/mcgraw-hill-moves-downtown-says-goodbye-to-namesake-building/|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=14 July 2015}} [[Hugo Boss]] moved its North American headquarters to the Financial District in 2015, leaving RXR Realty’s Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street.{{cite web|title=Hugo Boss moves North American HQ to FiDi’s 55 Water St|url=https://therealdeal.com/2014/11/21/hugo-boss-moves-north-american-hq-to-fidis-55-water-st/|publisher=The Real Deal|accessdate=21 Nov 2014}} ==See also== *{{Portal-inline|New York City}} *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|55 Water Street}} *{{official website|http://www.55water.com/}} *[http://www.emporis.com/building/55waterstreet-newyorkcity-ny-usa Emporis] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1972]] [[Category:Emery Roth buildings]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:Privately owned public spaces]] [[Category:1972 establishments in New York (state)]]

{{For|other people with a similar name|Alexander Lebedev (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Alexander Lebedev | image = Alexander Lebedev, Non-Executive Director, Independent and Evening Standard - Chatham House 2012.jpg | image_size = | caption = Lebedev at [[Chatham House]] in 2012 | birth_name = Alexander Yevgenievich Lebedev | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|12|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] (now [[Russia]]) | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations]] | occupation = Businessman | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = former [[KGB]] officer | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = {{Plainlist| * Natalia Vladimirovna Sokolova (separated 1998) * Elena Perminova}} | parents = {{Plainlist| * Yevgeny Nikolaevich Lebedev * Maria Sergeyevna}} | children = 4, including [[Evgeny Lebedev]] | relations = [[Vladimir Sokolov (scientist)|Vladimir Sokolov]] (former father-in-law) | website = }} {{ Listen| filename= Aleksandr Lebedev voice.oga |title= Alexander Lebedev's voice |type= speech |description= recorded March 2013 }}
'''Alexander Yevgenievich Lebedev''' ({{lang-rus|Алекса́ндр Евге́ньевич Ле́бедев|p=ɐlʲɪˈksandr jɪvˈɡʲenʲjɪvʲɪtɕ ˈlʲebʲɪdʲɪf}}; born 16 December 1959) is a [[Russians|Russian]] [[businessman]], referred to as one of the [[Russian oligarchs]].
In early 2008, he was one of the golden 100 top Russian billionaires listed as the 39th richest Russian worth an estimated [[United States dollar|US$]]3.1 billion by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine, but by October 2008 he was worth only $300 million.<ref name=Guardian081024>{{cite news | last = Harding | first = Luke | title = Twilight of the oligarchs: Communism's collapse made them multi-billionaires, but now Russian capitalism is in trouble. Can their colossal fortunes survive the downturn, or is this the end of an era? | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/oct/25/russian-oligarchs-oleg-deripaska | newspaper = The Guardian | date = 24 October 2018 | access-date = 12 May 2018}}</ref> In March 2012, he was listed by ''Forbes'' magazine as one of the richest Russians with an estimated fortune of [[United States dollar|US$]]1.1 billion. His fortune has since declined, and he is no longer considered to be a billionaire.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/alexander-lebedev/ |title=Alexander Lebedev |website=Forbes.com |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> He is part owner of the Russian newspaper ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]''<ref name=Times>{{cite news|last1=Elliott|first1=John|last2=Ungoed-Thomas|first2=Jon|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/tycoon-linked-with-litvinenko-survived-poisoning-cpklclqbfn7|title=Tycoon linked with Litvinenko 'survived poisoning'|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=7 January 2007|accessdate=12 June 2018}} {{subscription required}}</ref> and owner of two UK newspapers with son [[Evgeny Lebedev]]: the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' and ''[[The Independent]]''.
== Early life and education == Alexander Lebedev was born in [[Moscow]]. His parents were part of the Moscow [[intelligentsia]]. His father, Yevgeny Nikolaevich Lebedev, was an elite athlete–a member of the Soviet national [[water polo]] team, and later a professor at the [[Moscow State Technical University|Bauman Moscow State Technical University]], Moscow's highest technical school. After graduating from Moscow Pedagogic Institute, Alexander's mother, Maria Sergeyevna, worked in a rural [[Sakhalin]] school and later taught English in a Moscow tertiary school.<ref name=Pers>{{cite web|url=http://www.alebedev.ru/biograph/index.htm |title=Archived item |accessdate=13 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006123109/http://www.alebedev.ru/biograph/index.htm |archivedate=6 October 2007 }}</ref>
In 1977, Alexander Lebedev entered the Department of Economics at [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations]]. After he graduated in 1982, Lebedev started work at the Institute of Economics of the World Socialist System doing research for his [[Kandidat]] (between master's degree and doctorate) dissertation, ''The problems of debt and the challenges of globalization''. He transferred to the [[First Chief Directorate]] (Foreign Intelligence) of [[KGB]]. According to ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', as a KGB spy, he was based at the Russian embassy in London during the 1980s.<ref name=Times/> He worked for the KGB's successor, the [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|Foreign Intelligence Service]], until 1992.<ref name=Pers/> Lebedev had the diplomatic cover of an economics [[attaché]]. According to his personal website, Lebedev's assignments included fighting [[capital flight]] from the Russian Federation.<ref name=Pers/>
==Business career== [[File:Vladimir Putin 7 May 2002-4.jpg|thumb|right|Lebedev with [[President of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] on 7 May 2002]] Upon leaving the Russian intelligence community, Lebedev set up his first company, the Russian Investment-Finance Company. In 1995 this bought the [[National Reserve Bank (Russia)|National Reserve Bank]], a small Russian bank which was in trouble at the time. The bank subsequently grew rapidly to become one of Russia's largest banks. It and the [[Alfa-Bank]] were the only two out of the ten biggest Russian banks to survive the [[1998 Russian financial crisis]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Harding |first=Luke |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/11/alexander-lebedev-russia-oligarch | title=Alexander Lebedev: an oligarch we could learn to love |work=[[The Observer]]|date=11 January 2009 |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=London}}</ref> Among the bank's assets are: * 11% of the main Russian national airline [[Aeroflot]]<ref name="Leb_BNE">{{cite web|url=http://www.bne.eu/story4206/Alexander_Lebedev_cashing_out_of_Russia |title=Archived item |accessdate=22 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111102042/http://www.bne.eu/story4206/Alexander_Lebedev_cashing_out_of_Russia |archivedate=11 November 2012 }}</ref> * 44% of the [[Ilyushin]] Finance Co, that owns a significant share of Russian aircraft-building industry * significant parts of [[Sberbank]], [[Gazprom]], [[RAO UES]] The bank is the core of the group of companies holding National Reserve Corporation, that according to Lebedev's personal site owns around US$2 billion of assets.<ref name=Pers/> In March 2006, ''Forbes'' estimates Lebedev's fortune as high as US$3.5 billion,<ref name=Forbes/> but as of July 2013 he dropped out of the billionaires list and is no longer considered to be a billionaire.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/eiif45gddj/alexander-lebedev-2/ |title=Alexander Lebedev|page=9 |work=Forbes|date= |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
The National Reserve Corporation included the National Land Company (the biggest potato producer in Russia), National Housing Corporation (construction of affordable houses), National Mortgage Company (Национальная Ипотечная Компания), as well as interests in [[textiles]], [[telecommunications]], [[tram]]s and [[trolleybus]]es, [[electrical power industry|electrical power]], [[chemical industry|chemical]] and [[tourist industry|tourist]] industries owning a large hotel network in [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]] and plan to create the National Reserve Park that will manage diverse tourist enterprises in Russia, Ukraine and [[France]].
Lebedev used to own the ''[[Moskovski Korrespondent]]'', but according to [[Channel 4]]'s ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]]'' programme, Lebedev closed it down "for political reasons after it published a spurious article about Vladimir Putin having an affair with an Olympic gymnast half his age".<ref>Jon Ungoed-Thomas and Marie Woolf [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article6936282.ece "Oligarchs hire ‘do-nothing’ peers to boost their prestige",] ''The Sunday Times'', 29 November 2009</ref>
On 21 January 2009, Lebedev and his company [[Evening Press Corporation (UK)]], part of Lebedev Holdings, bought approximately a 75.1% of share in the ''[[London Evening Standard|Evening Standard]]'' newspaper for £1. The previous owners, the [[Daily Mail and General Trust]], continue to hold 24.9% in the company in the new firm, named [[Evening Standard Ltd]]. Lebedev promised to not interfere with the editorial running of the paper. Lebedev commented that during his time as a spy in London, he used the ''Evening Standard'' to find information.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7841891.stm|title=Ex-KGB spy buys UK paper for £1|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 January 2009|accessdate=21 January 2009}}</ref> [[Paul Dacre]], the editor-in-chief of the ''Evening Standard'' at the time of the sale said: "It's a very sad day for the paper, it's a very sad day for the [[Viscount Rothermere|Rothermeres]]. We are very sorry that it leaked out, we had no control over that. Everyone's been working very hard and there's a lot of hope for the future of the ''Evening Standard''."<ref>{{cite news |last=Brook |first=Stephen |author2=Sweney, Mark |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/21/alexander-lebedev-london-evening-standard1 |title=Alexander Lebedev's Evening Standard takeover: Dacre announces sale to staff |work=[[The Guardian]]''|date=21 January 2009 |accessdate=21 January 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
In 2009 he entered into exclusive negotiations with [[Independent News & Media]] to buy the company's British national newspapers, ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''Independent on Sunday''. Before the purchase was completed, his representatives offered the editorship of ''The Independent'' to [[Rod Liddle]], former editor of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s [[Today (BBC Radio 4)|''Today'' Programme]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sweney|first1=Mark|last2=Brook|first2=Stephen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jan/08/rod-liddle-edit-independent|title=Rod Liddle lined up to edit ''Independent''|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=8 January 2010|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> The offer was withdrawn after Liddle's putative appointment was opposed by the newspaper's staff and by a campaign online.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2010/jan/11/theindependent-simon-kelner|title=Independent faces revolt from staff and readers if Liddle becomes editor|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=11 January 2010|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Brook|first=Stephen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2010/feb/19/rod-liddle-independent|title=Rod Liddle no longer in running for Independent editor|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=19 February 2010|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> On 25 March 2010, Lebedev bought ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''Independent on Sunday'' for £1.<ref name="BBC2">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8587469.stm|title=The Independent bought by Lebedev for £1|publisher=BBC News|date=25 March 2010|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref>
In 2012, National Reserve Bank (NRB) faced difficulties: corporate deposits decreased by 2.2bn rubles, retail deposits by 1.2bn rubles. 20% of the bank's liabilities had run off by the end of January 2012. In March 2012, two top managers left the bank.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://top.rbc.ru/economics/12/03/2012/641345.shtml |title=НРБ продолжают покидать высокопоставленные сотрудники :: Экономика :: РБК |website=Top.rbc.ru |date=22 December 2016 |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
On 5 November 2012, Lebedev announced he would close all the regional offices of the National Reserve Bank and sell off the real estate as well as 75% of the bank's loan portfolio, worth 16.8bn rubles ($542m). Also in November 2012, Lebedev announced that he is selling off his assets in Russia.<ref name="Leb_BNE" />
== Legal ==
In September 2011 while appearing on a Russian television programme, he punched a fellow guest, billionaire property developer [[Sergei Polonsky]] ([[:ru:Полонский, Сергей Юрьевич|Сергей Юрьевич Полонский]]).<ref>{{YouTube|0UUwb9aXmVQ|''Alexandre Lebedev punches another CEO on Live Russian TV''}}</ref> Lebedev claimed afterwards that he had reacted to Polonsky's threat of violence towards him.<ref>{{cite news |last=Siddique |first=Haroon |title=Alexander Lebedev in Russian TV punch-up |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/sep/18/alexander-lebedev-russian-tv-punchup |accessdate=5 May 2015 |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=18 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Sergei-Polonsky_7C0B.html | work=Forbes | title=#962 Sergei Polonsky | date=5 March 2008}}</ref> Lebedev was later charged with [[hooliganism]] and sentenced to [[community service]] for that incident.<ref name="Leb_BNE" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19732368|title=Russian tycoon Alexander Lebedev charged over punch-up|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref>
== Political career ==
In 2003, Lebedev stood as a candidate for elections to the Mayoralty of Moscow and the [[State Duma]]. He received 13% in the Mayoral elections, losing to [[Yuriy Luzhkov]], but won a seat in the State Duma on the [[Rodina (political party)|Rodina]] party list (he was actually number one on the Moscow regional list of the party). He remained in the Duma until 2007, when new elections were held. In the Duma, he initially moved from nationalist Rodina to the pro-Government [[United Russia]] fraction,<ref name=Pers/> but after Rodina was merged into the larger social-democratic coalition [[Fair Russia]], he made his return.
Lebedev was formerly the Vice Chairman of Duma's committee on the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]], the coordinator of Duma's group on interactions with [[Verkhovna Rada]] of [[Ukraine]], and the coordinator of the State Duma group dealing with the city.<ref name=Pers/>
Lebedev, together with the former President of the [[Soviet Union]], [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], is the owner of 49% of ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', one of the most vocal newspapers critical of the current Russian Government.<ref name=WPNG>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/07/AR2006060701166_pf.html Peter Finn "Gorbachëv Invests in Newspaper",] ''[[Washington Post]]'', 8 June 2006, p.A17</ref>
After the [[Anna Politkovskaya assassination|assassination]] of a prominent ''Novaya Gazeta'' journalist [[Anna Politkovskaya]], Lebedev praised in print the talents of Politkovskaya and suggested her assassins were actually trying to target the good names of her opponents.<ref name=LebedevPoitkovskaya>[http://2006.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2006/77n/n77n-s46.shtml Alexander Lebedev "Shooting Anna Polikovskaya They Targeted Her Opponents",] ''Novaya Gazeta'', 9 October 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707140438/http://2006.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2006/77n/n77n-s46.shtml |date=7 July 2007 }}</ref> He pledged 25 million [[Russian ruble]]s (around US$1 million) for the information leading to the arrest of the assassins.<ref name=LebedevPoitkovskaya/>
Lebedev is a founder and the President of the National Investment Council, a non-political and non-government organization working to improve the investment sentiments in Russia, protecting interests of the Russian business abroad, and fighting the [[Anti-Russian sentiment|negative sentiments]] towards Russian business.<ref name=Pers/>
In September 2008, Russian politician [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] announced he was going to make a comeback to Russian politics along with Lebedev.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blomfield |first=Adrian |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/3104623/Mikhail-Gorbachev-returns-to-Russian-politics.html |title=Mikhail Gorbachev returns to Russian politics |publisher=Telegraph |date=29 September 2008 |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> Their party was called the [[Independent Democratic Party of Russia]].
In March 2009, Lebedev announced that he would be running for mayor of [[Sochi]], host of the [[2014 Winter Olympics]],<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/more/03/16/sochi.mayor.ap/index.html Lebedev Running For Sochi Mayor] SI.com, 16 March 2009</ref> but a court ruling declared his candidacy invalid on 13 April 2009.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/13/court-disqualifies-lebedev-sochi-mayor-race Alexander Lebedev disqualified from Sochi mayoral race] ''The Guardian'' (London), 13 April 2009</ref> The court ruling was a result of a complaint by another candidate, Vladimir Turukhanovsky, that Lebedev's campaign received three donations from minors that is forbidden by Russian electoral law. According to the chief of Lebedev's electoral campaign, Artyom Artyomov, the three teenagers were led to [[Sberbank]] by a staff member of the Sochi council, given 500 [[ruble]]s each (approximately $20), and told to donate the money to Lebedev's campaign. His campaigners sent the money back the same day, it was received but still it was found sufficient to disqualify his candidacy. Lebedev said that he intended to appeal the court's decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1155244|script-title=ru:Александра Лебедева отослали переводом|last=Тирмастэ|first=Мария-Луиза|date=14 April 2009|work=[[Kommersant]] N66 (4121)|language=Russian|accessdate=14 April 2009}}</ref>
==Charity== Lebedev has a long history of supporting culture and charity, and created an organization named Charitable Reserve Fund (Благотворительный Резервный Фонд, BRF) to bring order to these activities. Among the organizations and projects he (or BRF) have sponsored are:<ref name=Pers/> * Center for Children's [[Hematology]] and [[Transplantology]], named after [[Raisa Gorbachyova]] in [[Saint Petersburg]] (general sponsor of the construction) * Burdenko Military Hospital * [[State Russian Museum]] * Fomenko Theater * [[Moscow Art Theatre]] * Lesya Ukrainka Russian Theater in [[Kiev]] * Museum of [[Mikhail Bulgakov]] in Kiev * Restoration of the monument to [[Alexander Suvorov]] in [[Swiss Alps]] * Monument ''Sorrow'' (Скорбящая) in London by sculptor Sergey Shcherbakov commemorating Soviet soldiers who died during [[World War II]].
In October 2008, Lebedev met with [[Tom Stoppard]], [[John Malkovich]], and [[Kevin Spacey]] to discuss a new [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]] festival in [[Crimea, Ukraine]].{{fact|date=May 2018}}
Lebedev was awarded the [[Saint Innokenty of Moscow Order]] by the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] and the ''Dialogue of Cultures'' medal by [[UNESCO]].
==Personal life== Lebedev's first wife was Natalia Vladimirovna Sokolova, daughter of the scientist [[Vladimir Sokolov (scientist)|Vladimir Sokolov]], with whom he has one child, [[Evgeny Lebedev]]. They separated in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianmind.eu/content/press-baron-and-his-son |title=The Press Baron and His Son |website=Russianmind.eu |date= |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
Lebedev's second wife is Elena Perminova, a former model, with whom he has three children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/columns/ellie-pithers/TMG9908333/Whos-that-girl-Elena-Perminova.html |title=Who's that girl? Elena Perminova |website=Fashion.telegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>

[[File:Antonio marcegaglia.jpg|thumb|Antonio Marcegaglia]]
'''Antonio Marcegaglia''' (born in [[Mantua]] on 12 December 1963) is an [[Italians|Italian]] [[managing director]], Chairman and CEO of [[Marcegaglia]]; the leading industrial group in steel manufacturing.
==Biography== Antonio Marcegaglia obtained an honours degree in business studies from Milan’s Luigi Bocconi University in 1987 and joined the [[Marcegaglia]] full-time a few days later. He forged an indissoluble bond between his personal career and the growth of this fine mid-sized Italian company of those days, later transforming it into today’s major global player.
Led by Antonio Marcegaglia, the diversification of the group was then extended with the establishment of Bioindustrie Mantovane and the acquisition of Oskar of Osteria Grande (Bologna), Nuova Omec, Ennepi of Lugo di Romagna (Ravenna) and Imat of Fontanafredda (Pordenone) in 1988 and of CCT of Gallarate (Varese) and Elet.Ca of Capalle (Florence) in 1989, as well as the foundation in 1989 of Marcegaglia Impianti of Saronno (Varese). In the same year, Marcegaglia acquired holdings in Fergallo of Motteggiana (Mantua), SIM of Sant'Atto (Teramo) and Elletre of Montebello Vicentino (Vicenza). In 1991 the Group acquired Resco Tubi of Cusago (Milan) and OMF of Fiume Veneto (Pordenone). In 1994 it acquired Brollo Profilati of Desio (Milan), later moved to the “former Breda” area just outside Milan, on a site totalling 8 [[hectare]]s purchased in 1996, and then in 1995 ETA Euro Tubi Acciaio of Milan, followed by a stake in Allu's of Sesto al Reghena (Pordenone).
The new business and production constellation enabled the group to have a presence also in the sectors of metal household items, electrostatic paint for metals and metal components for the electrical appliance industry. Meanwhile, its metallurgical sector grew with the production of fine stainless steel tubes and cold-rolled profiles.
In 1996, the Euro Energy Group was also established in order to create plants for the production of energy from renewable sources. In January 1997 Nuova Forsidera Spa,<ref>Corriere della Sera [http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1997/febbraio/06/Marcegaglia_rileva_Forsidera_co_0_9702068052.shtml Marcegaglia rileva Forsidera]</ref> specialising in steel cold rolling and galvanising processes, was acquired with its plants in Corsico (Milan) and Albignasego (Padua).
The group’s energy division was expanded in 1997 under the guidance of Antonio Marcegaglia with the establishment of Green Power, for the development of strategies and systems for energy generation through the gasification of waste and biomass. Further expansion came in 1998, with the creation of Boiler Expertise to design and construct the industrial and power boilers.
In that same year came the acquisition of Astra of Mezzolara, Budrio (Bologna), and the Siderplating establishment was also acquired, under the name of Marcegaglia San Giorgio of Nogaro (Udine), producing rolling mill plates.
Antonio Marcegaglia’s corporate development programme continued in 1999 with the acquisition of Morteo Nord of Pozzolo Formigaro (Alessandria),<ref>La Stampa [http://archivio.lastampa.it/LaStampaArchivio/main/History/tmpl_viewObj.jsp?objid=2340439 Marcegaglia: rilancio della Morteo in 3 anni] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722041446/http://archivio.lastampa.it/LaStampaArchivio/main/History/tmpl_viewObj.jsp?objid=2340439 |date=2011-07-22 }}</ref> and Ponteggi Dalmine of Milan, Graffignana (Lodi) and Potenza.
This was followed in 2001 by the acquisition, in the tourism sector, of the holiday resort of Pugnochiuso, situated on the Gargano promontory in Apulia.
In December 2001, following an investment of over 500 million euros over very few years, a large new centre of production was opened in Ravenna, the second largest iron and steel centre in Italy. And in 2002, in the former Belleli area in Taranto, its second largest production plant in the South, after the one in Potenza, entered into operation
In 2003, the sector of products for the household electrical appliance industry expanded further with the acquisition of BVB of San Lorenzo in Campo (Pesaro). While in 2004 the group took a fundamental step in the development of its activities in the tourism sector by acquiring, with Banca Intesa and the Ifil group, 49% of Sviluppo Italia Turismo
In 2007 Antonio Marcegaglia acquired the stake in Gabetti Property Solutions and upgraded the Ravenna plant with a further investment of 300 million euros. The Group continued its expansion in the energy sector where, with its subsidiary Arendi, began production of photovoltaic panels. Likewise, its presence in tourism grew further with the acquisition of the management of Forte Village of Santa Margherita di Pula, in Sardinia, the largest hotel complex in Italy and Europe. This was followed soon after by the “Le Tonnare” holiday resort in Stintino, in the province of Sassari. In 2007 the production plant at Boltiere (Bergamo) was also enlarged. In 2008 the Group acquired the holiday location at Castel Monastero di Castelnuovo Berardenga (Siena) and the "Former Arsenale" property complex at La Maddalena (Sassari).
Since 2017, following the assignment of the Ilva Group to AM Investco (the joint-venture consisting of ArcelorMittal and [[Marcegaglia]]), Antonio Marcegaglia has been promoting the relaunch of this great European steelworks asset. The objective is to strengthen its position as a market leader and to increase the company’s market share in the European and World iron and steel works industry.
== Internationalisation of the Group == In 1989, Antonio Marcegaglia launched the Marcegaglia Group’s internationalisation policy which has strengthened its direct presence in the international markets.
Marcegaglia Deutschland of Düsseldorf was established in 1989 for the distribution of the Group’s own products on the German market and in Scandinavia. United Stainless Steel was also created in the UK near London, followed by Marcegaglia U.K., for the production of welded tubes from hot and cold rolled strip, and then by Marcegaglia UK at Dudley, West Midlands.
In 1991 Antonio Marcegaglia launched the project which would see the group enter into the transatlantic markets. In the second half of the year The New Bishop Tube of Philadelphia was acquired in the US, and, in February 1992, Damascus of Greenville. Two major production units which then led to the creation of Damascus-Bishop Tube Company, specialising in the production of stainless steel.
In 1993 Antonio Marcegaglia acquired the Belgian Cotubel group, a distributor of stainless steel products and tubes in France and Benelux, and founded the trading company Central Bright Steel for the distribution of welded tubes in the UK; it also began production of these same products near Birmingham in 1997.
In the summer of 1998, a large industrial area in Munhall, near Pittsburgh, was acquired to accommodate the new Marcegaglia USA, which would also incorporate the Damascus-Bishop Tube Company.
During the same period, two other companies were formed in the United States, as subsidiaries of the parent companies in Italy: Oskar Usa in Birmingham (Alabama) and Oto Mills Usa in Wheaton (Illinois).
In 1999 Antonio Marcegaglia’s efforts led to the incorporation of Marcegaglia Iberica, Marcegaglia Ireland, Marcegaglia France, Marcegaglia Austria and Marcegaglia do Brasil, the latter tripling its turnover by 2005, extending its plant and taking the number of its employees to 1000. Meanwhile in Bremen, in joint venture with the Arbed Group, the first Marcegaglia company to produce quality steel was formed.
In 2000, the Group acquired Earcanal of Leioa, Spain. Following the joint venture with Arbed, in 2004 the Marcegaglia Group signed an agreement with the Corus group for the 10-year co-management of its British steelworks on Teesside, guaranteeing the supply at cost price of one million tonnes per year of slabs for the production of coils and sheets. Oto Mills do Brasil was founded in San Paolo in the same year.
In 2005 the Group proceeded with the expansion of Marcegaglia do Brasil, and in June Antonio Marcegaglia opened its fourth overseas production plant in Praszka (Poland), to manufacture tubes for refrigeration, panels and corrugated steel sheets. One year later, 20 kilometres away, the plant at Kluczbork was added, for the production of tubes and drawn products. Marcegaglia established Marcegaglia Gulf at Doha, Qatar in 2007. The expansion of its industrial activities continued in 2008 with its entry into China, where, in [[Yangzhou]], 350 km north-west of Shanghai,<ref>Agichina24 - [http://www.agichina24.it/repository/canali/norme-e-tributi/notizie/200803130200-rt2-ss20080313027aaa-art.html Marcegaglia investe a Shanghai]</ref> it created its first Asian plant for the production of stainless steel tubes and high-precision carbon steel, with the establishment of Marcegaglia Romania at [[Cluj-Napoca|Cluj]], and with the start of work on the new production plant at [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], Russia.
In October 2013, following the passing of his father Steno, founder of the group, Antonio Marcegaglia is appointed Chairman of [[Marcegaglia]] group.<ref>[http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/regioni/lombardia/2013/10/04/Marcegaglia-Antonio-Emma-presidenti_9408448.html Marcegaglia: Antonio ed Emma presidenti -]</ref><ref>[http://www.italiaoggi.it/news/dettaglio_news.asp?id=201310041542505307&chkAgenzie=ITALIAOGGI Marcegaglia, il timone passa a Antonio ed Emma -]</ref><ref>[http://www.borsaitaliana.it/borsa/notizie/radiocor/finanza/dettaglio/nRC_04102013_1631_286118702.html Marcegaglia: Antonio presidente, Emma ai vertici Marfin -] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105164646/http://www.borsaitaliana.it/borsa/notizie/radiocor/finanza/dettaglio/nRC_04102013_1631_286118702.html |date=November 5, 2013 }}</ref>
==Ordinance== Antonio Marcegaglia has been awarded Stainless Steel Executive of the Year 2010 at 9th Stainless & Special Steel Summit in Rome<ref>Stahleisen.de - [http://www3.stahleisen.de/Content/News/AktuelleNews/Newsentry/tabid/360/sni%5B847%5D/8225/language/de-DE/Default.aspx Antonio Marcegaglia has been awarded Stainless Steel Executive of the Year 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719085303/http://www3.stahleisen.de/Content/News/AktuelleNews/Newsentry/tabid/360/sni%5B847%5D/8225/language/de-DE/Default.aspx |date=2011-07-19 }}</ref>

Prince [[Ivan Sergeyevich Obolensky|Ivan Obolensky]] (grandson) }} '''Ava Lowle Willing''' (September 15, 1868 – June 9, 1958) was an American socialite. She was the first wife of Colonel [[John Jacob Astor IV]] and later married [[Thomas Lister, 4th Baron Ribblesdale]]. ==Early life== Ava Lowle Willing was born on September 15, 1868 in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], to Edward Shippen Willing (1822-1906) and Alice Bell Barton (1833-1903).{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Will of E. S. Willing. Son Gets Bulk of Estate. The Daughters $225,000 Each. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/04/27/101776407.pdf |quote=The bulk of the $1,000,000 left by Edward S. Willing, who died at his residence, 510 South Broad Street, on April 10, is devised to his son, John R. Barton Willing, and his two daughters, Ava Lowle Willing Astor, wife of John Jacob Astor, and [[Susan Ridgway Willing]] Lawrence, widow of Francis Cooper Lawrence, Jr.|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 27, 1906 |accessdate=2008-08-11 | format=PDF}} She had three elder siblings: (1) [[Susan Ridgway Willing]] (1862-1940) who married on November 3, 1899, Francis Cooper Lawrence Jr. (1858-1904), they had no issue; (2) [[John Rhea Barton Willing]] (1864-1913) he died from [[pneumonia]] unmarried with no issue; and (3) Edward Shippen Willing Jr. (1867-1873) he died at age six. ==Personal life== ===First marriage=== On February 17, 1891, she married Colonel [[John Jacob Astor IV|John Jacob "Jack" Astor IV]] (1864–1912), son of [[William Backhouse Astor, Jr.]] (1829–1892) and [[Caroline Webster Schermerhorn Astor|Caroline Webster "Lina" Schermerhorn]] (1830–1908), at her parents mansion at 510 South Broad Street in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. They went on a 5-week honeymoon in [[Europe]].{{cite web|title=Colonel John Jacob Astor IV|url=http://www.titanicpages.com/1stclass/johnjacobastor|publisher=Titanic History Website}} The newlywed couple was given, among many lavish gifts, a furnished townhouse on Fifth Avenue in New York City.http://www.biography.com/people/madeleine-force-astor-283808#early-life Though the marriage was tumultuous, the Astors had two children: *[[Vincent Astor|William Vincent Astor]] (November 15, 1891 – February 3, 1959){{cite web|url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com/node/1902816 |publisher=New York Social Diary|title=Astor Legacy|accessdate=2010-07-27}} *[[Ava Alice Muriel Astor]] (July 7, 1902 – July 19, 1956){{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Lost Will Disposes Of $5,305,000 Estate |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1956/07/20/archives/mrs-pleydellbouverie-dies-here-daughter-of-col-john-jacob-astor.html |quote=Surrogate William T. Collins admitted to probate yesterday the lost will of Mrs. Ava Pleydell-Bouverie, which disposes of her $5,305,000 estate. She was the sister of Vincent Astor. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1956 |accessdate=2009-02-17}} The family lived in their New York townhouse at [[Mrs. William B. Astor House|840 Fifth Avenue]], their 2,000 acre country estate, [[Ferncliff forest|Ferncliff]] in [[Rhinebeck, New York]], and [[Beechwood (Astor mansion)|Beechwood]], their [[Newport, Rhode Island]] mansion. By 1896, Mrs. Ava Astor had become socially active in England. She had a country estate, [[Sutton Place, Surrey|Sutton Place]] in [[Guildford, Surrey]], and a townhouse on [[Grosvenor Square]] in [[Mayfair, London]]. In 1909, after returning from England, Ava sued Jack for divorce on November 19, and four months later on March 5, 1910, the [[State of New York]] decreed in her favor. She received a $10 million ({{Inflation|US|10000000|1910|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) settlement.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Would Probably Share $100,000,000 Estate with Stepmother in Event of His Father's Death. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1912/04/17/archives/vincent-astor-as-head-of-his-family-would-probably-share-100000000.html |quote=Mrs. Ava Willing Astor, obtained her divorce from John Jacob Astor, in November, 1909 |work=The New York Times |date=April 17, 1912 |accessdate=2008-08-11 }} Their son lived with his father before leaving to attend [[Harvard University]]. While Ava got custody of their seven-year-old daughter. While Vincent was in his second year at Harvard, Jack was on the maiden voyage of the [[RMS Titanic]], and became one of the casualties while returning from his honeymoon with his new bride, [[Madeleine Astor|Madeleine Talmage Force]].{{cite news |title=Son for Mrs. Astor. Named for Father. Both Mother and Baby Said to be Very Well, the Child Strong and Well Formed. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1912/08/15/archives/son-for-mrs-astor-named-for-father-both-mother-and-baby-said-to-be.html |quote=Baby is the Sixth John Jacob Astor. Mrs. Madeleine Force Astor, survivor of the Titanic..... |newspaper=The New York Times|publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr. |date=August 15, 1912|accessdate=June 22, 2008 }} This event left young Vincent{{cite web|title=Astor Estate Goes To Son|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QupgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u2MNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2415,1723472&dq=madeleine+force+astor&hl=en|publisher=The Evening News|date=7 May 1912}} as one of the wealthiest men in the United States.{{cite web|title=Astor Bequests Have All Been Paid|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/astor-bequests-have-all-been-paid.html|newspaper=The New York Times|publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.|accessdate=20 April 2012}} ===Second marriage=== In September 1911, Ava and her daughter moved to England. They lived in her townhouse on Grosvenor Square in Mayfair, London (from October–April) and her country estate, Sutton Place in Guildford, Surrey (from May–September). When [[World War I]] broke out, Ava became involved with the [[American Women’s War Relief Fund|American Women's War Relief Fund]] and she served as the group's vice-president.{{Cite news|url=https://americanwomeninwwi.wordpress.com/2017/01/09/helping-in-britain-the-american-womens-war-relief-fund/|title=Helping in Britain: The American Women’s War Relief Fund.|last=|first=|date=2017-01-09|work=American Women in World War I|access-date=2018-04-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927022703/https://americanwomeninwwi.wordpress.com/2017/01/09/helping-in-britain-the-american-womens-war-relief-fund/|archive-date=27 September 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19595598/|title=Two Hospitals for U.S. Troops Wounded|last=|first=|date=20 June 1917|work=Salisbury Evening Post|access-date=2018-04-27|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}} On June 3, 1919, Ava married [[Thomas Lister, 4th Baron Ribblesdale]] at [[St Mary's, Bryanston Square]] in [[London]] and she was known as Lady Ribblesdale. Lister died six years later on October 21, 1925, at their townhouse on Grosvenor Square in Mayfair, London. They had no children together and after Baron Ribblesdale's death, she did not remarry. He was buried in the Lister vault at [[St Mary the Virgin Churchyard (Gisburn)|St Mary the Virgin Churchyard]] in [[Gisburn]], [[Lancashire]]. In June 1940, she returned to the United States on the liner {{SS|President Roosevelt|1921|6}} as a war refugee, reclaimed her American citizenship, and became known as Mrs. Ava Willing Ribblesdale. ===Death=== On June 9, 1958, Ava died in her apartment at [[720 Park Avenue]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]] and she was buried in [[Trinity Church Cemetery]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Lady Ribblesdale Dead. First Wife of John Jacob Astor IV. Mother of Vincent Astor. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1958/06/11/archives/ldy-rissiedte-dead-at-sgii-first-wifeof-j-ohn-jacobastori-i-widow.html |quote= Ava Willing Ribblesdale, she took up residence here. She continued to be listed in the telephone directory as Lady Ribblesdale..... |work=The New York Times|date=June 11, 1958 |accessdate=2008-08-11 }} She left a token bequest of $25,000 to her son, Vincent, but the bulk of her $3,000,000 estate was left to her daughter Alice's four children: Prince [[Ivan Sergeyevich Obolensky]], Princess Sylvia Sergeyevna Obolensky Guirey, Romana von Hofmannsthal McEwen, and Emily Edwina Harding. ==See also== *[[Astor family]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{commons category|Ava Willing Astor}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Willing, Ava Lowle}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1958 deaths]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:British baronesses]] [[Category:Gilded Age]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:People from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Burials at Trinity Church Cemetery]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]
